div.p:
It was extremely kind in you to remem ber u sus and send
the remaining volumes of your work, anand I beg leave to tender you
my hearty thanks for your generosity. You no doubt recollected the
time when you were placed in similar but much more unfavourable cir-
cumstances and kindly sympathised with us. Many thanks for your kind-
ness.

We have been prevented from going at once up to the Makolo coun-
try by a wretched sham of a vessel - rue of the contraction for which
promised before we got it that she should carry ten or twelve tons
and the other declared after we got it that she was designed to carry
only a few "a very few persons". Well this piece of honesty led us up the
Sshire and to the discovery of two magnificent Lakes. The country ad-
jacent to them is elevated and very beautiful, and so far we have had no
reason to regret the delay. We are now anxiously expecting a steamer
capable of ascending the rapids which from what we observed at low
water we suppose passable when the river is in flood but should it
not make its appearance we shall proceed on foot or in a whaler in
about 6 weeks.
With good wishes for your health Happiness

I beg leave to congratulate you on the honour conferred by Her
Majesty the Queen.
